content: The House and Senate passed their respective National Defense Authorization Acts for Fiscal Year 2017, containing provisions affecting military personnel. A conference committee was convened to reconcile differences between the two versions. The House and Senate passed their respective National Defense Authorization Acts for Fiscal Year 2017, containing provisions affecting military personnel. A conference committee was convened to resolve differences between the versions, leading to the final bill being signed into law on December 23, 2016. This report highlights selected personnel-related issues of congressional and constituent interest. Related CRS products are referenced for more detailed information and analysis. Congressional interest in military personnel costs and quality remains focused on the annual military pay raise. The military pay raise is of long-standing congressional interest to recruit and retain high-quality personnel in the all-volunteer military. Section 1009 of Title 37 US Code provides for an annual increase in basic pay indexed to the Employment Cost Index. The increase for 2017 is set at 2.1% unless Congress or the President specifies otherwise. Pay raises typically take effect at the start of the calendar year. The military pay raise for 2017 is set at 2.1% unless Congress or the President specifies otherwise. In the past three years, the President used alternative pay adjustment authority to set the raise below the ECI. The FY2017 President's Budget requested a 1.6% raise, lower than the statutory formula. The House bill aimed to require the statutory raise. The FY2017 President's Budget requested a 1.6% military pay raise, lower than the statutory formula of 2.1%. The House bill aimed to require the statutory raise of 2.1%, while the Senate bill proposed a 1.6% increase. The enacted bill specified a 2.1% pay raise for all servicemembers effective January 1, 2017. The enacted bill specified a 2.1% increase in basic pay for military personnel, effective January 1, 2017, waiving the automatic adjustment of 1.6%. Under current law, all servicemembers are entitled to government-provided housing or a housing allowance known as Basic Allowance for Housing (BAH), based on paygrade, geographic location, and dependency status. The Basic Allowance for Housing (BAH) is determined by paygrade, geographic location, and dependency status to provide servicemembers with appropriate housing options. BAH rates vary by location but ensure comparable housing for servicemembers of similar rank and dependent status. The Senate bill proposed changes to how Basic Allowance for Housing (BAH) is calculated, focusing on geographic location and paygrade rather than dependents. It would base BAH on actual housing expenses up to a maximum amount for a specific location/paygrade, instead of a set rate. The Senate bill proposed changes to Basic Allowance for Housing (BAH), focusing on location and paygrade instead of dependents. It would calculate BAH based on actual housing expenses up to a maximum amount for a specific location/paygrade, and adjust the allowance for servicemembers sharing living quarters. The new formula for Basic Allowance for Housing (BAH) would apply to certain members of the Armed Forces starting January 1, 2018. It would limit the allowance for members sharing housing based on the total number of occupants. The enacted bill requires DOD to provide a report to the House and Senate Armed Services Committee by March 1, 2017 on transitioning certain reserve and retired personnel ordered to active duty, and servicemembers entitled to BAH on December 31, 2017, who lose eligibility for housing allowance. The military retirement system underwent changes in the National Defense Authorization Act for FY2016 to modernize and reduce retired pay benefits, including a reduced pay multiplier, a 401k-type defined contribution element, partial lump-sum payment option, and continuation pay as a retention incentive. These changes will take effect on January 1, 2018. The military retirement system will undergo changes on January 1, 2018, including reducing the retired pay multiplier, adding a 401k-type defined contribution element, allowing for a partial lump-sum payment of retired pay, and introducing continuation pay as a retention incentive. These changes will apply to servicemembers entering on or after that date and those with 12 years or less of service who choose to enroll in the new system.
